container-title: • B.E.R.T.H.A. doesn't understand the negative form of words. Always teach her facts using the positive form of a word
note: For example, B.E.R.T.H.A. understands best when you say "Apples grow on trees," rather than, "Apples do not grow on vines." • B.E.R.T.H.A. has trouble understanding the verb "can." For example, instead of describing a bird by saying, "It can fly," tell B.E.R.T.H.A.,"ltflys." Or tell B.E.R.T.H.A., "Apples are red, green, or golden" rather than, "Apples can be red, green, or golden."
title: one fact at a time about an object
Tell me something about an apple," she remembers best when you answer, "An apple grows on a tree

An apple grows on a tree and an apple is a fruit" is too much for her to remember at one time. Every time B.E.R.T.H.A. guesses what you're thinking of, she will ask you for another fact about that object
Tell me something else about an apple" you can tell her, "An apple is a fruit
